Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 05:36AM WolfsLady wrote: It's my understanding that you should still see the surgeon.  Not seeing it on imaging doesn't mean it's cancer, but it doesn't mean it's nothing either.   I think they usually biopsy things that can be felt but not seen.  Just to make sure.  I would guess it's very low risk (someone else will have to weigh in on that) but with your family history you want to know that it at least looks benign.  All my stuff has been seen on ultrasound, but not mammograms.  So far everything has come back benign.  There are tons of benign things that can be going on in your breast and I should know I have about a 1/2 a dozen of them.  Most lumps are harmless if annoying and lymph-nodes can give you troubles for all sorts of reasons too.  I'd say to try and relax but that doesn't usually work well so I'll just wish you luck.
Posts.Title: Lump not showing up on mammogram or ultrasound DeAnaR Nemmett44

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 10:55PM WolfsLady wrote: The only thing I've seen is that micropapillomas are usually found as more than 1 and it's the multiple that is thought to make them more risky.  They are also more often found in the small ducts that are further out. I'm not sure that there is a difference in the cells themselves so much as the size.  I have a single papilloma, that is being watched.  Part of me wishes they would just remove it and be sure that nothing else is lurking there with it.  I was assured that it was very, very small when they called about the biopsy results.  But at about 4mm it's not that small.  I'm not sure where it is exactly.  I know that this biopsy was a lot more painful than the one I had for a fibroadenoma 16 months earlier.  It's good to hear that if I ever do need this one removed that it might not be as painful as I was.  It's been almost 2 weeks and I'm still very tender and I still can't sleep on my stomach without some pain.  I'm wondering if that is normal.  I thought I'd give until Wed (2 weeks) and call my doctor to ask.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Question about micropapilloma and core needle biopsies graciesd Petitegal127

Posts.Content: May 29, 2014 10:45PM WolfsLady wrote: I'm sorry that you are getting the run around.  The waiting is so frustrating.  I'm not sure what 2 weeks is going to do.   I do hope that you get answers soon.  I'm not sure why in your case they don't just do the biopsy since it's the only way to be sure.
Posts.Title: Got mammography reports: says focal asymmetry Kris10mo leaf

Posts.Content: May 19, 2014 05:17AM - edited May 19, 2014 05:18AM by WolfsLady Sorry you haven't gotten an answer.  I've heard from a few people that the indentation filled back in.  Not sure if that's true for everyone, or even most people, or not.  No one seems to say much about that and I guess compared to what so many are going though it really isn't a big deal.  I'd just like to know what to expect, since I didn't expect pain for this long after my core biopsy.  But I'm also a bit OCD and it might make me a little crazy if I ended up too lopsided.  If I ever needed to have a mastectomy I think I'd just have to do both sides.   I can understand why you would want a reduction and if you can get them to reduce to get everything even I say go for it.  My best friend had a reduction and she was so glad that she did.  I do have a friend who didn't fill back in after surgery but she said her doctor removed a lot of tissue (benign) and she wasn't quite B to start with.  She ended up getting implants to even things out and put her at a full B.  Only she gained weight and a lot of it went to her chest so now she's a DD and she wants to have the implants removed.   I know you read that I'm having the same thing removed and nervous too.  Mine is in the large ducts and I only have 1.  However it has other benign changes with it.  I worry about having so many different things in one small area that was biopsied.  Here is what my biopsy report says: Sections of core needle biopsies show and intraductal papilloma with areas of severe usual ductal hyperplasia and apocrine papillary hyperlasia. - interductal papilloma with focal sever usual ductal hyperplasia. - apocrine papillary hyperplasia - microcysts with apocrine metaplasis I will be having mine out on the 27th so I won't be any help in letting you know how it goes.  Hopefully with much less anxiety, pain and drama than we worry about. I'm sorry that your family is going through so much. I am very thankful that neither of my parents have been touched by cancer.  (My dad has had some pre-cancer stuff removed but nothing breast related.  His father had and 2 of his sisters have breast cancer.)   I'll send prayers to you and your family..
Posts.Title: Intraductal Papilloma & Breast Reduction AlwaysInThrees AlwaysInThrees

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 02:15AM - edited Mar 21, 2014 02:20AM by WolfsLady I take Xanax for my PTSD related anxiety.  It was really bad while going through all the breast stuff.  Works well for me.   4mm is really small.  That's what they told me anyway it's what my papilloma that they biopsied was.   It was not found on my last Mammogram/US last spring.  May I think.  It was 7 months (I had a bad cold when I was supposed to do my 6 month MRI and had one of those panic attacks 1/2 way through because I couldn't breathe.)  The spot they biopsied was seen on there and on the new US.  When I had my first biopsy there a month lapse between the ultrasound they found it on and the biopsy and in that short time I had developed a 2nd one right next to the first.  I never understood how I could get another one when I heard they are estrogen driven and my estrogen level was only 15.  I hope this reassures you that benign things can grow quickly in your breast.    Oh my husband has Raynards and it's some freaky looking stuff when your hands do that isn't it.  They can't find any reason for his.  From what I read it's very common for them to not find any cause.  He's like you always cold.  Drives me nuts because I'm always hot.  It will get down to 74 and he will want a fire in the house.  I have to threaten him with bodily harm if he dares to burn so much as twig at that ungodly temp.  I do empathise but I point out that he can put on a sweat shirt and gloves and stay warm.  With our 6 year old in the house there is only so much I can take off.
Posts.Title: I got "called back" for additonal views. I'm very scared! curlynski edwards750

Posts.Content: May 1, 2014 04:31PM WolfsLady wrote: Thank you so much.  I think one thing I'm really worried about is that they will do the surgery because I'm having pain but that I'll end up with even more pain.  But times like right now it feels like someone is sticking a needle in my nipple and wiggling it around.  Painful enough that I want to cry.  I'm not sure if having my period is amplifying it or if it's just getting worse.  My other breast has the normal achy feeling I get at this time.  Which is nothing I even notice much.  However part of me wonders if the pain is God's way of saying that this needs to come out.  After all there is still a lot of controversy over rather this is a precursor to cancer.  Most doctors remove them right away because of the possible risk.  And my doctor backtracked on her "no increased risk" to say "It only slightly increases your risk."   I guess with my family history and all these changes I don't totally trust that there isn't something more brewing.
Posts.Title: Pain after core biopsy - papilloma - Probable excisional biopsy WolfsLady WolfsLady

Posts.Content: May 11, 2014 04:27AM WolfsLady wrote: I'm sorry that no one has answered.  I have no idea but didn't want to leave you hanging.  If it was me I'd keep asking until I got answers.
Posts.Title: Confused? SD36 SD36

Posts.Content: WolfsLady wrote:  Has anyone had pain that lasted this long and it was noting?  Can anyone tell me what the excisional biopsy is like and will I loose feeling in my nipple since I know it's directly under it?  I saw my doctor today and she is recommending a diagnostic mammogram and US but she feels that I will most likely need to have an excisional biopsy.   Her thoughts are that either my papilloma has grown or just started irritating the ducts or that the clip has moved and is causing my pain.  Either way she feels like as long as we're in there we should take everything out and biopsy it.  I say we but she isn't the breast surgeon I have to see her after the tests.  There is a slim chance that it could be a hematoma, but she doesn't think that or an infection is likely.  I guess right now I'm more worried that it could be pain from the core biopsy and if it is that when they do the excisional biopsy it will be even worse.   I also got my final biopsy results today.  When she called she just told me that it was an intraductal papilloma.  There were other things on there that I haven't had time to research yet.  I hate how so many things sound sort of like the bad things, but they are totally benign.  I guess that's what I'm dealing with here.  But if anyone has had any of this and can give me their thoughts.   She did spend some time justifying her feeling that we could wait to remove it and just do short term follow ups.  She said at one point that Dr M. (the breast surgeon) would probably have suggested that we remove it right away if I'd been seeing her when the biopsy results first came in.  But that they felt that things like this were safe to watch for awhile.  I'd done some research so I knew that most doctors removed papillomas and I was still OK with leaving it as long as it wasn't causing problems or growing.  I'm nervous about future pain and what if this doesn't take care of.   Here is what my biopsy report says: Sections of core needle biopsies show and intraductal papilloma with areas of severe usual ductal hyperplasia and apocrine papillary hyperlasia.    - interductal papilloma with focal sever usual ductal hyperplasia. - apocrine papillary hyperplasia - microcysts with aporine metaplasis My last biopsy said benign (fibroadenoma) on it, but I don't see that anywhere on this.  Nor do I see a recommendation from the pathologist.  My last biopsy had that too, (6 month follow ups for 2 years)  Which is what my doctor has me doing anyway because of family history.   Thank you.   High Risk: Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pain after core biopsy - papilloma - Probable excisional biopsy WolfsLady WolfsLady

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2014 12:29AM WolfsLady wrote: Mine isn't until next week and my anxiety is crazy high.  I keep telling myself it's only a BIRADS 4 and they added - low suspicion - but it's not helping.  I got a script for Xanax, but I hate to take anything so I've only taken a few.  This is taking so long...  Because of my family history my doctor wanted to do an MRI 6 months from my last mammogram.  I was sick and had to delay it a month, which was no big deal.  Except they did the MRI Dec 12.  It took my doctor until after the new year to get the results.  Still wasn't anxious so much as frustrated at that point.   They wanted to do a follow up ultrasound.  Which I had on January 6th. I could see that they saw something new and the tech told me that my doctor should have the results tomorrow.  The other times they had always said a few days.  Took me until Feb 5th to get the results.  (I got them before my doctor did.)   Another week to send them to place she wanted the biopsy done and for them to review them.  All with my anxiety rising.  I haven't been sleeping well either and my son has been being super challenging.   Here's hoping that we all get big fat B9's.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Results, Anxiety is HIGH ldyblu77 sydney2013

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2014 01:44AM WolfsLady wrote: I had my first breast MRI this year and I got a call back an US. (UltraSound)  I wasn't really concerned because I'd been warned that MRI's give a lot of false positives.  The US was rated BIRADS 4 and a biopsy was recommended.  Because the hospital I had the US at sucked it took me a month to get my US results that told me that and I was a wreck.  I knew during the US that they had seen something because they measured it.  Then because I was in a different state it took time to send my records and have another radiologist look at them before they would schedule anything.  At first I wasn't really worried but the longer it took the more I started to.  Thankfully I was in the majority and my biopsy came back as benign.  Just keep in mind that you have only gotten a call back for an US and they can tell a lot just from that.  We added those to my mammogram because of dense breasts and family history.  You might consider talking to your doctor about doing that if it will make you feel better.  (I do the 6 months either mammogram or MRI too.)  To me being proactive is empowering.  But it means that we might discover benign things that others never even know they have.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Rough week Mudhonie WolfsLady

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2014 02:34PM WolfsLady wrote: Hugs.
Posts.Title: Highly Suggestive of Malignancy AlienWish angelaisscared

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2014 05:15AM WolfsLady wrote: Of course it's a choice only you can make.  It's a huge surgery.  But I hear you about the constant worry and multiple biopsies.  One thing I'd want to know is how many can you have before all the scar tissue from those starts to make it too easy to miss things or just makes it so that you are going to need another biopsy every 6 months when you get scanned?  I've had 2 core biopsies (one was a 2 fer)  and an excisional biopsy.   While I am very thankful that all have been benign the excision was multiple papillomas which are considered to raise your risk of breast cancer.  I also have Aunts, cousins and a grandfather who have had breast cancer so that already had me in the higher risk group.  It's not clear if the 2 together change anything since there are limited studies on papillomas.  I'm going to assume not.  :)  but I'm being well monitored and I'm counting on that to catch anything that might dare to grow early.  For me that's enough.    At least for now.  But I can't say that it would be if one of my sisters or brothers was diagnosed.  I would say that if it was a brother unless he carried a gene that I don't, the girls are getting upgraded for sure.  For me the best thing seems to be to have a plan for certain scenarios and to play the rest by ear.   My motto for years has been "Hope for the best - Prepare for the worst."   That doesn't mean to sit around and micro plan or assume that the worst will happen.  It just means when you are on the plane of life know where the emergency exits and flotation devices are.  Then sit back and try to enjoy the flight no matter how bumpy it gets.  If you decide that what you have might be defective and new flotation devices are going to make the flight less worrisome why shouldn't you get them?   :)
Posts.Title: Decisions Colleen_2 Colleen_2

Posts.Content: May 13, 2014 01:44PM WolfsLady wrote: Melissa the post that got to me wasn't yours.  At least I don't think so.  Although I think you gently suggested that she might not hang out here so much to help lower her anxiety so I was responding to that too.  The post that made me feel bad for her was one that listed the number of post she's made and how many thread's she's started when she doesn't have bc.  Anxiety is a hard thing to deal with and when you are left feeling like you don't have the answers it really helps to talk to someone who has been through that worry.  Who might have the answers.  I tried to ask about my biopsy results (I was told I had a papilloma but when I got the report it listed other B9 changes too.  I was concerned about having 3 different B9 changes in one spot.)  I tried asking on a parent's off topic board I belong to, but I didn't get any answers.  So I came back here, but no one seems to know.  They just focus on the "B9 isn't that great!"  Yes it is.  But it won't do me any good to pretend that it can't turn into something if it can and I don't want to be one of the women who comes back here with an "I wish I'd known." story.   And like Alicki said it's hard to trust doctor's when you don't feel like you're getting answers to your questions.  Even more so when you've been burned by 1 or more doctors in the past.  I hate doctors who feel like we shouldn't ask questions.  Just trust them.  I won't make that mistake again.  I think it's fine to encourage someone to look for answers in the right places or even to just empathize with them if you don't have the answers.  If you are so inclined to ignore the and hope they will move on.  I just didn't think it was OK to throw in her face how much she had posted.  And no I didn't go "stalk" her to see what she had posted and where.  I looked at this thread because I thought I might get some helpful answers and that even if I didn't that I could understand.  I look here and I'm amazed at how quickly some women get their results.  It seems sometimes like it's a few days to a week from mammogram to biopsy results.  A few will be a little longer.  I wish so much my stuff would go that way.  Maybe my anxiety wouldn't build up as much.  But it's been over a month between my BIRAD's rating and my biopsy both times.  Then a week for the biopsy results.  And both times I've been good with the b9 results although a few people have questioned my not insisting that they take out the growths anyway.  Especially the papilloma.  I was fine with waiting until the pain started getting worse.  Now I'm back in limbo again focused on my breast and what is going on in there to cause pain.  I go to a Women's Hospital for my mammograms and between 3 places they could send me it's taking weeks to get a diagnostic mammogram, while I sit here in pain.  To me it is unacceptable to make women wait that long when there is anything concerning going on.   I'm seeing the breast surgeon on Wed even though I won't have the mammogram until the 22nd. (Unless something opens up sooner)  Not that they have ever seen anything I've had on a mammogram.  I know my anxiety is being kicked up by not only that but the frequent stabbing pains in my breast.  I hate to take any medication but I've taken pain meds or anxiety meds more often over the last 4 weeks than I like too.  I never even like to take them when I went through my worst stage after I was attacked (attempted kidnapping) many years ago.  They do help, I just don't like the way they make me feel even in the lowest doses.  So the trade off has to be worth it.  I've been trying some yoga because a friend said it really helped with her PTSD anxiety.  I've also found jogging to be very therapeutic and helpful.  However I don't feel like doing it when I'm in pain an wondering if something is wrong that I could make worse if I do it.  So I feel trapped a bit when I want to go running.  (If you can call my slow pace running.  LOL)  But it might help someone else with theirs.  I highly recommend the C25K program. (Couch to 5K)  It really is amazing.  Although some people have to repeat weeks (or add days) like I did the first time I started it.  There is no shame in that.  When I had to restart it after a back injury toward the end I didn't have to repeat any days.  If you've ever thought it might be fun to jog, but "I could never do that" give it a try.  I amazed myself and I wish I'd tried 20 year and a lot of pounds ago.  Really though any kind of exercise can help with anxiety.  It also releases endorphins which helps with your mood in other ways.    I'd love to hear other suggestions.
Posts.Title: How do you deal with the anxiety? alicki sarahjane7374

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 10:29PM WolfsLady wrote: I would rather be proactive and get tested over something that isn't, than miss something because I was worried about being silly.   I hope everything turns out to be fine.
Posts.Title: Fibercystic Breast tissue-Left breast always causing me trouble. CCrill CCrill

Posts.Content: May 11, 2014 07:49PM WolfsLady wrote: I think you do what you have to in order to make yourself feel better.  It seems to me that they wouldn't have forum's for "High Risk" and "Waiting for Results" under the heading "Not Diagnosed but Concerned" if they didn't want people to use them.  When I look on these boards I don't feel as anxious or alone.  I don't feel bad about worrying because no one here is telling me that it's wrong to do so.  At least I didn't feel that way until I read the post here about how many posts you made and how many threads you started when you haven't been diagnosed with BC.  God willing we will never find ourselves knowing what that feels like.  But I feel prepared and empowered knowing that I'm making sure that I am informed about things to watch out for.  Having been misdiagnosed on another medical condition for years I say that you should go with your gut if you are worried that the doctors are missing something or dismissing something you are concerned about without putting your fears to rest.  Doctors aren't God and there are some out there who ruin peoples lives because they act like they are.  Demand answers if that's what it takes.  If meds for anxiety help you then take them.  I take xanax when I have panic attacks.  But I suffer from PTSD.  Most of my anxiety with things with my breasts has been caused by long waits for answers.  I'm waiting again right now because I'm having pain after (since) a core biopsy in Feb.   They found several benign things in one area so I'm not really concerned that it will come back with anything else, but they are talking about doing an excisional biopsy.  Mostly worried that this won't help the pain or that it will cause more pain.  It helps me to connect with other women who are in the same boat.  Who know how it feels to have the extra risk no matter how slim it might be.  Because frankly some of us are going to end up drawing the short stick on that one.  Just as others have.   This is the best place I've found to get support but maybe there are others out there that I just haven't found.  I've felt good about trying to give a few words of comfort to women who are worried and waiting for results from the perspective of someone who got good news.  Now it seems like it might bother some women on here that I am hanging around instead of moving on.  I think it would be a shame to drive women like us off.  What happens if we are Dx'd in the future and we don't feel comfortable coming back here?  Sad.
Posts.Title: How do you deal with the anxiety? alicki sarahjane7374

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2014 07:43AM WolfsLady wrote: What an awesome idea.  I wish I could have found a post or a website somewhere that give info on this from the woman's point of view.   I used a different place, but everyone was really great with mine too.  Much less stressful than I expected even though I forgot to ask my doctor for something to calm my panic attacks.  I did have a really bad one when they moved my surgery time back by an hour, but they let my 6 year old come back to the pre op area and keep me company (even though it said no one under the age of 12 could come back) so that really helped.   If I ever need a wire placement again I'll ask for what you had.  Mine wasn't nearly as comfortable as yours sounds.  But it seems like it was done differently than it seems like MOST are.  Even with that I would call it extremely uncomfortable, not unbearable or anything.  If anyone is interested it's under my thread about having a papilloma excised.  Most everything was much less traumatic than I expected.  Even having the crazy wire sticking out for a couple of hours.  Out of the whole thing what bothered me most was a reaction I had to the tegaderm tape.  The blisters I got were awful and 1 week out I still have an area that isn't totally healed. Which isn't surprising since the area was so raw that it was bleeding for at least 3 days.  I mention this because the nurse indicated that quite a few people have reactions to that clear film so if anyone is having pain away from their incision site they should ask their doctor about this possibility.  I should add that I have had reactions to other bandages.   I hope this helps other women to not be so frightened.  If anyone has any questions about my papilloma surgery feel free to contact me.  My surgeon in Houston did a great job and everything looks much better than I imagined it would.  I know that we all worry about that too.
Posts.Title: Guided wire excisional biopsy: my experience Mamafid WolfsLady

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2014 08:01AM WolfsLady wrote: I'm sorry you can't get clear answers.  There seems to be so much grey area in breast related growths.  Especially when you have multiple b9 conditions.   And if you have a doctor or doctor's giving you conflicting information it can make it even worse.  If you've been do a doctor or doctors who misdiagnosed you or a loved on in the past you realize that they aren't infallible.  You know something is wrong with you.  You know that your breasts are growing things and you have to wonder if the 2 aren't related.  I'm like you I would like definitive answers.  You are right to expect them.  And if the doctor thinks that there is a chance they could have missed something then you are right to be concerned  However I would like to caution you not to get too focused on what is going on in your breasts and not get other things checked.  It can be easy to do that.  If you haven't already get checked for other female problems and digestive issues.  Like someone above said they are more likely to cause weight loss.  Also have your thyroid checked if you haven't already.  It took me 5 doctors and YEARS to get my thyroid problem dxed.  By the time they discovered it, it was really out of whack.  It was criminal that so many doctors dismissed my concerns and fading health without ever running such a simple test.  You might also research other health conditions that might cause b9 breast growths.  I don't know that there are any but if there are it might explain some of what you are going through.   Let us know what your biopsy says when you get it.   As for the women who are berating you for being here, I'm sorry.  I don't know how anyone is going to decide where to draw a line on this subject.  I believe a moderator weighed in in the past and stated that women with breast concerns were welcome on these "not dx'd but worried" boards.  I'm sure that there are more than a few women who were here getting b9 results, in the past who crossed over to the other side weeks, months or even years later.  B9 doesn't give you pass on this.  It simply says what we tested didn't show cancer.  To deny future risk is like taking cover under a tree when there is a storm warning.  Yes there's a good chance you won't get hit but there is no guarantee.  And we owe it to ourselves to feel confident that the doctors have given us the correct answer.  I would urge any woman (anxiety or not) to feel like her doctor isn't missing something or dismissing her without clear answers.
Posts.Title: Infamous lymph nodes and fat necrosis alicki alicki

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2014 06:54AM WolfsLady wrote: If you have core biopsy and it's a papilloma they are most likely going to recommend removing it anyway.  A single papilloma is low risk for cancer, but rarely they do hide cancer. It does sound like typical papilloma symptoms.  I wasn't going to have mine removed because I had no symptoms, but I started having stabbing pains so it's gone now.  Having a simple biopsy is likely not going to stop the discharge or the pain.  The surgery wasn't that bad.  You can check out my posts if you want.  The changes are taking some getting used to but my doctor says that if it's still bothering me after 6 months I can have corrective surgery.  Don't get me wrong they are not huge changes and I feel like I'm being too vain letting them bother me.  Mostly I'm a bit OCD and they don't match now.  That side droops more and the nipple doesn't point the way the other one does.  I don't even notice it as much looking in the mirror as I do looking down when I'm taking a shower or getting dressed.  Pain was minimal.  I don't even think I took pain pills after the first day.  Certainly it was less noticeable than the awful stabbing pains that I had for over 2 months before the surgery.  Let me know if you have any questions.
Posts.Title: 7 mm mass directly under nipple Pattyshothouse whatnow

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2014 09:33AM WolfsLady wrote: I agree that only including 1st degree relatives is a huge flaw.  In my case breast cancer risk runs higher on my dad's side than my mom's.  At least 2 of his sisters and his father were dx'd between the ages of 48 and 54.  My sisters are all younger than I am and of the 3 cousins I had that were older I only know the medical history of 1.  A 2nd one possibly had some sort of cancer but her mom is secretive and they are semi-estranged and they live so far away that no one in my family has seen her since she was about 4 years old.  My secretive aunt and another of my dad's sisters had hysterectomies in their late 20's or early 30's for what they were told was cancer but once again no one seems to know what kind.  One was his sister who died in her 60's of unknown causes.  She was mentally ill.  Her daughter, my 3rd older cousin died in an auto accident in her 20's.  My dad had bladder cancer about 5 years ago but unlike his sisters and his father he was older.  Thankfully they caught it early.  My doctor told me that since 2 of them possibly had their ovaries removed that it could have lowered their cancer risk because they wouldn't produce estrogen.  At least one of my Aunts was estrogen positive.   At any rate by leaving out family history they discount that 4 of my father's 5 sisters had a "female" cancer.  Plus his father.   And lower my risk because my younger sisters, who are 3 and 8 years younger than I, haven't had cancer.   On my mom's side so far her mother and her were both blessed to have been spared breast cancer.  Although my grandmother had many other health issues and she also had a hysterectomy pretty young, but I don't believe it was cancer related.  But both of my mom's grandmother's had breast cancer in their 50's.  One of her mom's sister's was dx'd in her 50's.  I don't believe her mom's other sister ever had it, but one of her daughter's was dx'd at 52 and her other daughter has just hit that age.  Hers was estrogen positive too. I'm hoping that the double generation skip (My mom is 70) means that if there was gene there it skipped our line.  But I know that I can't count on that.   I know that my risk was raised some because I didn't have my only child until I was over 40.  I worry because I took fertility meds for about 6 years trying to have him.   I also wonder if having busy breasts raises my risk at all.  But my mom says she had 2 extensional biopsies of benign masses so I guess her's were busy too.  (Her doctor back then recommended removing anything that grew because her grandmother's and aunt had breast cancer.)  But she doesn't seem to know what they were.  I'm guessing fibroadnomas since she was pretty young when she had it done.  Early 30's at the latest.  And that is what 2 of my masses are.  I can't believe how lax she is that she doesn't even know.  I just feel better knowing exactly what I had and rather the risk is very low or if I need to vigilant.
Posts.Title: High Risk - means what? How much time before you could have "c" someone_in_nj leaf

Posts.Content: May 10, 2014 06:56AM WolfsLady wrote: So glad it was benign!   You are so lucky that you got your results so quickly.  The woman here are so wonderful to take the time to give those of us who are worried and waiting encouragement.
Posts.Title: Benign results after indeterminate microcalcifications found Lovestorun333 Lovestorun333

Posts.Content: May 8, 2014 12:32AM WolfsLady wrote: Maybe no one really knows or just the wrong people are seeing it.  I am very confused on all on all of this, but at least I know that what they found is b9.  Not that it's helping much since I'm still in pain after my biopsy in Feb.  I'm looking at a mammogram and US to see if they can find anything new or my junk grew.  I'll most likely need an excisional biopsy to remove the stuff the core biopsy didn't get.  I thought it would be less stressful knowing what was there.  And I guess it is, but not a whole lot.  I hope everything goes well for you.  Let us know.
Posts.Title: Follow up and new questions dlgmom1 WolfsLady

Posts.Content: May 8, 2014 12:41AM WolfsLady wrote: I can' understand you're being a bit freaked out with your history.  My doc's kept reminding me that MRI's give a lot of false positives and I'm sure that with your history they would look even closer and take more care in noting anything.  I'm sure you know to ask about your BIRADS rating, that might set your mind a little more at ease.  But my MRI was BIRADS 4 and so wa my US.  Everything was B9.  Praying yours is too.
Posts.Title: Ultrasound following MRI Mumtobe WolfsLady

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 02:30AM WolfsLady wrote: I think about 10% of BIRAD's 5 turn out to be benign.  So there is hope for that.  Also if it's caught early and at a low grade it's usually very curable.  Even at higher stages they are coming up with new things all the time.  One of my Aunts is stage IV and she has been through a lot, but it's been 3 years and she is doing pretty good.  She told me that with her new meds she hasn't seen any growth in at least 6 months.  The doctor told her that if these meds can keep holding the cancer to where it is now, if they keep working there is a chance she could live another 10 or 15 years.  That's even if nothing new comes along.  I hope that's the truth.  Most of the other people I know were caught at stage II and all are doing well.  My other aunt is 3 years out and health.  My friend is 5+ years cancer free and my cousin is 10+.  Even many years ago my grandfather who was Dx'd in his early 50's lived into his mid to late 70's and I don't think his cancer ever returned.  Don't start worrying about being terminal, focus on how you are going fight if you get the Dx and how you are going to celebrate when you don't.  Sending good vibes.
Posts.Title: No answers from Dr. Calirose Sparklekat

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2014 08:44PM WolfsLady wrote: I just got the papilloma dx too.  I am BRAC neg though.  I know I'd be more of a wreck if it wasn't.  This whole thing is so hard.  Watching family and friends who have breast cancer and wondering if you are on the short list.  No one else in my family has been tested for any of the breast cancer genes so I don't even have the comfort of "Well they were positive so that means I am not high risk."  Now I have the papilloma in the same breast that I have a fibroadnomia.  And I guess I don't really trust the "no" or "very low" risk of becoming cancer thing.  Seems like someone is going to get the short stick on that and how reassuring will it be to them to hear how rare it is?  I had a rare side effect to a medication once.  So rare that no one I've ever talked to has ever heard of it and the first doctor I saw had no idea it what it was.   If you want someone to talk to you can send me a message.  I haven't even done much looking on what exactly a papilloma is or means.  Just enough to confirm that only one is much better than several.  And that my doctor wants to leave it be and watch it.  Which I'm not eager to do anything since I've had a lot more pain with this biopsy than I did with the one for the adenoma.  Do you mind me asking did you have pain in your nipple afterwards?  Anyway I just wanted you to know that I understand.
Posts.Title: so tired of waiting... jsjherman jsjherman

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 09:27PM WolfsLady wrote: I think it depends upon what sort of US you are having.  I didn't find out anything until weeks, or on this last one a month later, when I had my US's.  But I've heard of women being sent straight for a biopsy.  It could depend upon rather it's a routine test or rather they are following up on something that is very suspicious and they already have you lined up for one just in case.  I would expect that if they were thinking they might do one that day, that they would prepare you.
Posts.Title: Will I be given any info at ultrasound appointment? MissQ WolfsLady

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2014 01:47PM WolfsLady wrote: I want to go to the hospital's that some of you go to.  My fastest results were at private place.  Of course when I switched to the hospital and they said the prior scans weren't very good.  But nothing has showed up on any mammogram anyway.   This last US was done as a follow up to a preventive (family history) MRI. (The MRI was Dec 12th.)  When they made the appointment I was under the impression that I would get the results right away, since they told me they wanted to schedule it when the radiologist who read my MRI was there.  The tech told me "You will get the results tomorrow."  That was Jan. 6th.  It was Feb 5th before I was told BIRADS 4 and they want a biopsy.  That was with both my doctor and I calling and trying to figure out what the hold up was.  NO ONE should have to wait that long!  I don't ever want to use that hospital again.  My gut feeling right now is that it's B9, but if it isn't I've wasted over 2 months from the MRI date.   I'm hoping that you get your results fast.
Posts.Title: Will I be given any info at ultrasound appointment? MissQ WolfsLady

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2014 03:46AM WolfsLady wrote: Not sure if I should laugh or not.  I hope everything goes well tomorrow.  I would try not to focus on anything except your cute little nipple patch.  I had a friend who used to make these fancy shapes to stick over your nipples.  Maybe they could make those for the patches so you could at least look cute.  But I'd like some better gowns first.  The place I went today it's more like a cape and boy do you feel exposed.  One gust of wind and that suker is gone.  Sending a prayer.
Posts.Title: Guess I'm Back in Here ... Pokemom1959 SophiaMarie
